text: every year two million women are
diagnosed around the world with breast
cancer and 600,000 I that statistics are
really really striking and it's a crisis
that we have tried very hard to address
through better imaging tools teaching
people around the world how to read
mammograms and it's a challenge so I had
an opportunity to move to Boston and I
knew there would be a lot of change as I
moved from the west coast to the east
coast what I didn't know that I would
meet this fantastic woman
Regina Barzagli she had just finished
her own breast cancer treatment at the
age of 42 she was quite young when she
was diagnosed at a young son and one of
the men that recruited me to MGH in
Harvard said you've got to meet this
patient of mine you too will do great
things together and I wasn't sure why so
we met and she could not believe as a
computer science expert and our
artificial intelligence at MIT how
little information was available to
guide her treatment she also in her own
personal story realized that at 40 she
had her first mammogram they said she
had dense breast tissue but not to worry
about it that most women do fifty
percent of women are told they have
dense breast tissue at forty one the
same thing at forty two they said we see
something on your mammogram so you can
see here Regina she went through her
treatment and also her mammogram and as
we studied her mammograms together she
said could we have seen it last year or
even the year before with better tools
could we see it as distinct from all
that dense normal tissue that I have and
so we started our journey together using
the tools of AI she took her entire lab
at MIT that was not working in the
healthcare domain shifted the whole
group over to tackling our most
challenging problems for our patients in
breast cancer and we tackled problems
that our patients faced using large
large databases that we have in Boston
at Mass General Hospital and the
technologies that they developed at MIT
and deep learning so we found that we
could find cancers earlier and also that
we could use techniques
to find those cancers before humans were
finding them
so it wasn't unique to Regina that you
could look back and say maybe that was
the cancer developing then that's true
in about 30% of breast cancers that are
diagnosed and what we realized that
every woman's mammogram is unique to her
like a thumbprint and we could just in
the way that we saw how you could take
hundreds of thousands of images and sort
dogs from cats we could take hundreds of
thousands of images of mammograms and
because they're unique to each woman we
knew the outcomes of those women in the
future we could train the model to know
this is a woman who will develop cancer
in the future and this is a woman who
will not develop breast cancer in the
future many years before a human could
see anything on that mammogram that
looked like a cancer so we weren't using
old-school CAD where computer dated
detection where we would teach the
machine to learn what a cancer looks
like we were giving many tens of
thousands of mammograms with known
outcomes to the Machine and letting the
Machine learn from cues and signals that
we were not teaching it what we found in
our model was that we could predict into
the future for women in ways that none
of our existing risk models could do we
had our training set and our testing set
and then we actually implemented it into
a large group of women we found that we
could predict the future much better
than any existing models and most
importantly we remove the racial
disparities that we have been plagued
with in my my field
